author: Emmanuel Favre
title: Tennis: fin de carrière pour Eugénie Bouchard - lematin.ch
text:
Onze ans après avoir bousculé la hiérarchie du monde du tennis, Eugenie Bouchard raccrochera sa raquette à l’issue de l’Open de Montréal, qui aura lieu du 27 juillet au 7 août au Stade IGA. C’est sur Instagram que la Canadienne de 31 ans a communiqué la nouvelle, accompagnant son post de photos retraçant son parcours, depuis son enfance jusqu’aux aires de jeu les plus clinquantes.
«On sait quand c’est le moment. Pour moi, c’est maintenant. Terminer là où tout a commencé: Montréal», a-t-elle écrit.
Révélée en 2014, Bouchard avait enchaîné les exploits: demi-finales à l’Open d’Australie et à Roland-Garros, puis finale à Wimbledon, battue par la Tchèque Petra Kvitova. Sa puissance de frappe et sa régularité l’avaient rapidement propulsée au 5e rang mondial.
Mais la suite de sa carrière n’a pas confirmé les espoirs engendrés par ces débuts fracassants. Entre blessures, irrégularité et une lourde opération à l’épaule qui l’a éloignée des courts pendant 17 mois, Bouchard a glissé dans le classement. Elle pointe aujourd’hui au 1078e rang mondial. Sa dernière apparition en tournoi WTA remonte à la semaine dernière à Rhode Island, où elle a été éliminée d’entrée.
Passage éclair à Lausanne Championne junior à Wimbledon en 2012, Bouchard a aussi été victime d’un grave accident en 2015, glissant dans les vestiaires de l’US Open. Ce choc, qui lui a causé une commotion cérébrale, a donné lieu à une longue bataille judiciaire contre la Fédération américaine.
En 2019, elle avait été la tête d’affiche du Ladies Open de Lausanne. À Vidy, elle avait été éliminée dès le premier tour par l’Allemande Tamara Korpatsch après avoir obtenu une balle de match.
Gavin Ziv, directeur général de Tennis Canada, a salué l’impact de Bouchard: «Peu d’athlètes ont autant marqué le tennis canadien. Sa finale à Wimbledon et ses performances ont été un catalyseur pour notre sport. Elle restera une ambassadrice précieuse.»

author: Peter Akinbo
title: PSG seek further slash in Osimhen price
text: Paris Saint-Germain are still pushing for a lower transfer fee for Napoli striker Victor Osimhen, as they continue their pursuit of the Nigeria international this summer, PUNCH Sports Extra reports.

author: AFP
title: North Korea says US sale of military helicopters to South 'reckless'
text: SEOUL: North Korea on Thursday criticised recent US arms sales in Asia, calling a deal to deliver Apache helicopters to South Korea a "reckless, provocative act" and adding Pyongyang would build up its own forces in response. "We strongly oppose and reject the US and its vassal forces' arms buildup," North Korea's Foreign Ministry said in a statement, referring to the South. "This is a reckless, provocative act of deliberately increasing the security instability in the region," it added, also criticising recent US sales to Japan and other Asia-Pacific allies of Washington. The United States on Monday had announced its approval of a $3.5-billion sale to South Korea of up to 36 AH-64E Apache attack helicopters and related equipment, including missiles. The US Defense Security Cooperation Agency (DSCA) said the sale would "improve the Republic of Korea's capability to meet current and future threats by providing a credible force capable of deterring adversaries and participating in regional operations", using the formal name for South Korea. The State Department approved the possible sale of the helicopters to South Korea, and the DSCA on Monday provided the required notification to the US Congress, which still needs to sign off on the transaction. Washington is Seoul's key security ally and stations about 28,500 troops in South Korea, with their role including helping to protect it from its nuclear-armed neighbour. Pyongyang also said on Friday that US arms sales in the Pacific would prompt "the DPRK's strategic deterrence" to be "further strengthened" in response. "The prevailing situation urgently calls for thoroughly ensuring the military balance in the region by increasing the defence capabilities in every way in direct proportion to security challenges and threats that may result from the US arms sales," it said. The Democratic People's Republic of Korea, or DPRK, is the formal name for North Korea. The helicopter sale announcement came on the same day that Washington and Seoul began major annual joint military drills, with new exercises aimed at containing the North. The Ulchi Freedom Shield exercise runs until August 29 and will involve thousands of military personnel. author: @25newsweek
title: Pekin man convicted of attempting to entice a minor
text:
Pekin man convicted of attempting to entice a minor
PEORIA (25News Now) - A Pekin man was convicted Wednesday for attempting to entice a minor for sex.
The Department of Justice said the evidence against Joseph Perkins, 32, presented by the government, established that from January 2023 to March 2024, Perkins communicated on an internet-based social media platform with an individual he believed to be a 13-year-old girl, expressing multiple times that he wanted to engage in sex with her.
In March 2024, Perkins drove to a location in Peoria to meet the girl for the purpose of having sexual relations, according to the DOJ.
Federal law enforcement agents arrested him when he arrived at the location.
He is set to be sentenced on August 13.
The statutory penalties for attempted enticement of a minor are a minimum of ten years to life imprisonment, followed by a minimum five-year to life term of supervised release. Perkins remains in the custody of the U.S. Marshals Service.
